<H1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">List of Nobel laureates in Physics</H1>			<DIV id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
				<DIV id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</DIV>				<DIV id="contentSub"></DIV>
								<DIV id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<A href="#mw-head">navigation</A>, 					<A href="#p-search">search</A>
				</DIV>
				<DIV id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><DIV class="mw-parser-output"><DIV class="thumb tright">
<DIV class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><A href="/wiki/File:Nobel_medal.png" class="image"><IMG alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6a/Nobel_medal.png/200px-Nobel_medal.png" width="200" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6a/Nobel_medal.png/300px-Nobel_medal.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6a/Nobel_medal.png/400px-Nobel_medal.png 2x" data-file-width="1013" data-file-height="1013" /></A>
<DIV class="thumbcaption">
<DIV class="magnify"><A href="/wiki/File:Nobel_medal.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></A></DIV>
Front side (obverse) of the Nobel Prize Medal for Physics presented to <A href="/wiki/Edward_Victor_Appleton" title="Edward Victor Appleton">Edward Victor Appleton</A> in 1947</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P>The <A href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">Nobel Prize in Physics</A> (<A href="/wiki/Swedish_language" title="Swedish language">Swedish</A>: <I><SPAN lang="sv">Nobelpriset i fysik</SPAN></I>) is awarded annually by the <A href="/wiki/Royal_Swedish_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences">Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences</A> to scientists in the various fields of <A href="/wiki/Physics" title="Physics">physics</A>. It is one of the five <A href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel Prizes</A> established by the 1895 <A href="/wiki/Will_(law)" class="mw-redirect" title="Will (law)">will</A> of <A href="/wiki/Alfred_Nobel" title="Alfred Nobel">Alfred Nobel</A> (who died in 1896), awarded for outstanding contributions in physics.<SUP id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-1">[1]</A></SUP> As dictated by Nobel's will, the award is administered by the <A href="/wiki/Nobel_Foundation" title="Nobel Foundation">Nobel Foundation</A> and awarded by a committee that consists of five members elected by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.<SUP id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-2">[2]</A></SUP> The award is presented in <A href="/wiki/Stockholm" title="Stockholm">Stockholm</A> at an annual ceremony on December 10, the anniversary of Nobel's death.<SUP id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-3">[3]</A></SUP> Each recipient receives a medal, a diploma and a monetary award prize that has varied throughout the years.<SUP id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-4">[4]</A></SUP></P>
<P></P>
<DIV id="toc" class="toc">

<H2>Contents</H2>
<SPAN class="toctoggle"> [<A role="button" tabindex="0" class="togglelink">hide</A>] </SPAN></DIV>

<P></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Statistics">Statistics</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Nobel_laureates_in_Physics&action=edit&section=1" title="Edit section: Statistics">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<P>The first Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded in 1901 to <A href="/wiki/Wilhelm_R%C3%B6ntgen" title="Wilhelm Röntgen">Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen</A>, of Germany, who received 150,782 <A href="/wiki/Swedish_krona" title="Swedish krona">SEK</A>, which is equal to 7,731,004 SEK in December 2007. <A href="/wiki/John_Bardeen" title="John Bardeen">John Bardeen</A> is the only laureate to win the prize twice—in 1956 and 1972. <A href="/wiki/Maria_Sk%C5%82odowska-Curie" class="mw-redirect" title="Maria Skłodowska-Curie">Maria Skłodowska-Curie</A> also won two Nobel Prizes, for physics in 1903 and chemistry in 1911. <A href="/wiki/William_Lawrence_Bragg" class="mw-redirect" title="William Lawrence Bragg">William Lawrence Bragg</A> was, until October 2014, the youngest ever Nobel laureate; he won the prize in 1915 at the age of 25.<SUP id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-5">[5]</A></SUP> Two women have won the prize: Curie and <A href="/wiki/Maria_Goeppert-Mayer" title="Maria Goeppert-Mayer">Maria Goeppert-Mayer</A> (1963).<SUP id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-6">[6]</A></SUP> As of 2017, the prize has been awarded to 206 individuals. There have been six years in which the Nobel Prize in Physics was not awarded (1916, 1931, 1934, 1940–1942).</P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Laureates">Laureates</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Nobel_laureates_in_Physics&action=edit&section=2" title="Edit section: Laureates">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>

For the official pictures provided by the Nobel Foundation, see the pages for each Nobel laureate at nobelprize.org.</P>
<P><SPAN class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_2"><B><A href="#ref_2">^</A></B></SPAN> B. The information in the country column is according to nobelprize.org, the official website of the Nobel Foundation. This information may not necessarily reflect the recipient's birthplace or citizenship.</P>

For a full account of the work done by each Nobel laureate, please see the biography articles linked from the name column.</P>

<P><I><B>High School Musical 2</B></I> is the second film in the <A href="/wiki/High_School_Musical_(film_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="High School Musical (film series)"><I>High School Musical</I> series</A>. The World Premiere took place on August 14, 2007,<SUP id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-1">[1]</A></SUP> at Disneyland, in Anaheim, California. The primary cast, including <A href="/wiki/Zac_Efron" title="Zac Efron">Zac Efron</A>, <A href="/wiki/Vanessa_Hudgens" title="Vanessa Hudgens">Vanessa Hudgens</A>, <A href="/wiki/Ashley_Tisdale" title="Ashley Tisdale">Ashley Tisdale</A>, <A href="/wiki/Lucas_Grabeel" title="Lucas Grabeel">Lucas Grabeel</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Corbin_Bleu" title="Corbin Bleu">Corbin Bleu</A> attended the event. The film debuted on television on August 17, 2007, on <A href="/wiki/Disney_Channel" title="Disney Channel">Disney Channel</A> in the U.S., and on <A href="/wiki/Family_Channel_(Canadian_TV_network)" title="Family Channel (Canadian TV network)">Family</A> in Canada.</P>
<P>In the second installment of the Disney franchise, high school student Troy Bolton stresses over getting a <A href="/wiki/Employment" title="Employment">job</A>, with the price of <A href="/wiki/College" title="College">college</A> expenses looming on his mind, as well as trying to make sure he and Gabriella Montez are able to stay together all summer. This situation attracts the attention of Sharpay Evans, who attempts to steal Troy for herself by hiring him at her family's country club.</P>
<P>The premiere was seen by a total of over 17.2 million viewers<SUP id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-2">[2]</A></SUP> in the <A href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</A> which is almost 10 million more than its predecessor, making it the highest-rated Disney Channel Movie of all time as well as the highest-rated <A href="/wiki/Basic_cable" class="mw-redirect" title="Basic cable">basic cable</A> telecast at the time.<SUP id="cite_ref-patriots_3-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-patriots-3">[3]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-variety_4-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-variety-4">[4]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-5">[5]</A></SUP></P>
<P></P>

<P></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Plot">Plot</SPAN></H2>
<P>The school year ends with everyone at East High School looking forward to summer vacation ("What Time Is It"). Troy Bolton is still dating Gabriella Montez, who decides to stay in <A href="/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico" title="Albuquerque, New Mexico">Albuquerque</A> with her mother. Troy eventually decides to look for a summer job to gain money for college.</P>
<P>Sharpay and Ryan Evans plan to spend part of the summer at their family's country club, Lava Springs ("Fabulous"), but Sharpay's summer plans also include pursuing Troy, whom she has arranged to be hired at the club. However, Troy convinces the club's manager, Mr. Fulton, into hiring Gabriella and their close group of friends as well; including Taylor and Chad. Sharpay is enraged upon learning that Gabriella is working as one of the lifeguards, but is unable to get her fired. So she orders Fulton to give them difficult tasks so they would be best to quit. Fulton attempts to intimidate the group, but Troy rebuilds their confidence and convinces them that they can persevere ("Work This Out").</P>
<P>Troy continues to worry about funding for college. Sharpay senses his need and arranges for Troy to be promoted, hoping that this will convince him to sing with her at the talent show. Meanwhile, Kelsi writes a ballad for Troy and Gabriella. Troy agrees to sing with his friends in the show ("You Are The Music In Me"), not knowing that Sharpay is vying for his attention. (In the extended version, Sharpay and Ryan trap Troy as he prepares for a date with Gabriella, and perform their potential show-stopper ("Humuhumunukunukuapua'a").)</P>
<P>Ryan realizes he does not mean much to Sharpay anymore, as she is ready to blow her brother aside for the opportunity to perform with Troy. This leads to tension between the twin siblings and Ryan angrily informs Sharpay that he will no longer obey her orders. Taylor and Gabriella invite Ryan to the baseball game, where he persuades the Wildcats to take part in the talent show ("I Don't Dance").</P>
<P>Troy and Gabriella's relationship is strained when Troy sees Ryan with Gabriella, sparking jealousy. Owing to a "promise" from Troy, he and Sharpay practice their song for the Midsummer Night's Talent Show ("You Are The Music In Me (Sharpay Version)").</P>
<P>When Sharpay discovers that Ryan and the Wildcats are putting together their own performance in the show, she orders Mr. Fulton to ban all junior staff members from performing. Gabriella angrily confronts Sharpay about her interference and quits her job at Lava Springs. Troy overhears the exchange and tries to persuade Gabriella to change her mind. Gabriella expresses her loss of trust with Troy ("Gotta Go My Own Way") and leaves Lava Springs, and gives him the necklace back. It also seems that they broke up.</P>
<P>Troy returns to work the next day to find that his friends refuse to talk to him. Kelsi silently shows Troy the notice from Mr. Fulton, causing Troy to question his own motivations ("Bet On It"). He begins to reconcile with Chad and his other friends. Then Troy confronts Sharpay, informing her that he will not sing with her. The Wildcats and Chad forgive Troy for his absence and convince him to sing in the talent show, which he does only under the condition that they are all allowed to perform as well.</P>
<P>At Sharpay's supposed instruction, Ryan gives Troy a new song to learn moments before the show. As Troy goes onstage, he asks Sharpay why she switched the song, and Sharpay is shocked to find that her brother tricked her. Troy sings the song ("Everyday") alone until Gabriella surprisingly joins him onstage. In the end, Sharpay proudly presents her brother, Ryan, with the award for the talent show. After the talent show, all the Wildcats go to the golf course to enjoy the fireworks.</P>
<P>Everyone celebrates the end of the summer with a pool party ("All for One") which features a cameo appearance by <A href="/wiki/Miley_Cyrus" title="Miley Cyrus">Miley Cyrus</A>.</P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Cast">Cast</SPAN></H2>
<DIV role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <A href="/wiki/List_of_High_School_Musical_characters" title="List of High School Musical characters">List of High School Musical characters</A></DIV>
<UL>
<LI>Troy Bolton (<A href="/wiki/Zac_Efron" title="Zac Efron">Zac Efron</A>) is Gabriella's boyfriend, the most popular male student at <I>East High School</I> and the captain of the <A href="/wiki/Varsity_team" title="Varsity team">varsity</A> <A href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</A> team. For this movie, Efron did all of his own singing, whereas, in the first <I>High School Musical</I>, his singing was blended with singer <A href="/wiki/Drew_Seeley" title="Drew Seeley">Drew Seeley</A>'s voice.<SUP class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<I><A href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><SPAN title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2012)">citation needed</SPAN></A></I>]</SUP></LI>
<LI>Gabriella Montez (<A href="/wiki/Vanessa_Hudgens" title="Vanessa Hudgens">Vanessa Hudgens</A>) is Troy's girlfriend who is relieved that she will still be attending East High. She is the lifeguard at the Lava Springs Country Club until Sharpay's actions cause her to quit and break up with Troy.</LI>
<LI>Ryan Evans (<A href="/wiki/Lucas_Grabeel" title="Lucas Grabeel">Lucas Grabeel</A>) is Sharpay's <A href="/wiki/Twin" title="Twin">twin</A> brother who lives in the shadow of his <A href="/wiki/Primadonna" class="mw-redirect" title="Primadonna">primadonna</A> sister.</LI>
<LI>Sharpay Evans (<A href="/wiki/Ashley_Tisdale" title="Ashley Tisdale">Ashley Tisdale</A>) is Ryan's primadonna twin sister determined to win the talent show while also vying for Troy's attention and doing anything to help him.</LI>
<LI>Chad Danforth (<A href="/wiki/Corbin_Bleu" title="Corbin Bleu">Corbin Bleu</A>) is Troy's best friend and is very good friends with Jason and Zeke.</LI>
<LI>Taylor McKessie (<A href="/wiki/Monique_Coleman" title="Monique Coleman">Monique Coleman</A>) is Gabriella's best friend. She is also friends with Kelsi Nielsen and Martha Cox and is dating Chad. She is captain of the school Scholastic Decathlon team. She has a summer job at <I>Lava Springs</I> as an Activities Coordinator.</LI>
<LI>Thomas Fulton (Mark L. Taylor) is the manager of Lava Springs.</LI>
<LI>Coach Jack Bolton (<A href="/wiki/Bart_Johnson" title="Bart Johnson">Bart Johnson</A>) is Troy's father and East High's basketball coach.</LI>
<LI>Darby Evans (<A href="/wiki/Jessica_Tuck" title="Jessica Tuck">Jessica Tuck</A>) is Sharpay and Ryan's mother and president of the Lava Springs Board.</LI>
<LI>Vance Evans (<A href="/wiki/Robert_Curtis_Brown" title="Robert Curtis Brown">Robert Curtis Brown</A>) is Sharpay and Ryan's father.</LI>
<LI>Ms. Darbus (<A href="/wiki/Alyson_Reed" title="Alyson Reed">Alyson Reed</A>) is the stern drama teacher at East High.</LI>
<LI>Zeke Baylor (<A href="/wiki/Chris_Warren_Jr." title="Chris Warren Jr.">Chris Warren Jr.</A>) is friends with Troy and Chad and plays for the basketball team.</LI>
<LI>Jason Cross (<A href="/wiki/Ryne_Sanborn" title="Ryne Sanborn">Ryne Sanborn</A>) is friends with Troy, Chad, and Zeke and plays on the basketball team.</LI>
<LI>Kelsi Nielsen (<A href="/wiki/Olesya_Rulin" title="Olesya Rulin">Olesya Rulin</A>) is friends with Gabriella and Taylor and a <A href="/wiki/Pianist" title="Pianist">pianist</A> and <A href="/wiki/Composer" title="Composer">composer</A>.</LI>
<LI>Martha Cox (<A href="/wiki/Kaycee_Stroh" title="Kaycee Stroh">Kaycee Stroh</A>) is friends with Gabriella, Kelsi, and Taylor.</LI>
<LI>Jackie (<A href="/wiki/Tanya_Chisholm" title="Tanya Chisholm">Tanya Chisholm</A>) is one of Sharpay’s friends (a.k.a. The Sharpettes).</LI>
<LI>Lucille Bolton (<A href="/wiki/Leslie_Wing" title="Leslie Wing">Leslie Wing Pomeroy</A>) is Troy's mother.</LI>
<LI>Lea (Kelli Baker) is another Sharpette.</LI>
<LI>Emma (McCall Clark) is another Sharpette.</LI>
<LI>Unknown Wildcats player (<A href="/wiki/Shane_Harper" title="Shane Harper">Shane Harper</A>) is the principal dancer.</LI>
<LI>Girl At Pool (<A href="/wiki/Miley_Cyrus" title="Miley Cyrus">Miley Cyrus</A>) is an unknown dancer at the end (cameo).</LI>
</UL>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Release">Release</SPAN></H2>
<P>The premiere of <I>High School Musical 2</I> aired at 8 PM <A href="/wiki/Eastern_Time_Zone_(North_America)" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Time Zone (North America)">Eastern Time</A> on August 17, 2007, and included a telecast hosted by <A href="/wiki/Kenny_Ortega" title="Kenny Ortega">Kenny Ortega</A> and the movie's cast. On Saturday, August 18, <A href="/wiki/Disney_Channel" title="Disney Channel">Disney Channel</A> aired "High School Musical 2: Wildcat Chat", in which the stars of the movie answered questions posed by fans. On August 19, Disney aired a sing-along version of the movie.<SUP id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-6">[6]</A></SUP> On May 23, <A href="/wiki/DirecTV" title="DirecTV">DirecTV</A> announced that they would be hosting an exclusive <A href="/wiki/High-definition_video" title="High-definition video">high-definition</A> airing of the movie a few days after the August 17 premiere on its network-only channel, <A href="/wiki/The_101_Network" class="mw-redirect" title="The 101 Network">The 101</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-7">[7]</A></SUP></P>
<P><A href="/wiki/Disney_Channel" title="Disney Channel">Disney Channel</A> aired a weekly program called <I>Road to High School Musical 2</I>, beginning on June 8, 2007, and leading up to the premiere of <I>High School Musical 2</I> in August. The show offered viewers a behind-the-scenes look into the production of the movie. The world premiere of the opening number "<A href="/wiki/What_Time_Is_It%3F_(song)" title="What Time Is It? (song)">What Time Is It</A>" was on <A href="/wiki/Radio_Disney" title="Radio Disney">Radio Disney</A> May 25, 2007,<SUP id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-8">[8]</A></SUP> and similarly "You Are The Music In Me" premiered on July 13, 2007.<SUP id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-9">[9]</A></SUP></P>
<P>On December 11, 2007, the movie was released on DVD and Blu-ray titled <I>High School Musical 2: Extended Edition</I>. On September 15, 2008, a 2-disc special edition of the movie was released titled <I>High School Musical 2: Deluxe Dance Edition</I>.</P>

<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Reception">Reception</SPAN></H2>
<DIV class="thumb tright">
<DIV class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><A href="/wiki/File:HSM2.JPG" class="image"><IMG alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/HSM2.JPG/250px-HSM2.JPG" width="250" height="188" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/HSM2.JPG/375px-HSM2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/HSM2.JPG/500px-HSM2.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2816" data-file-height="2112" /></A>
<DIV class="thumbcaption">
<DIV class="magnify"><A href="/wiki/File:HSM2.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></A></DIV>
A performance of musical numbers from High School Musical 2 at Disney's Hollywood Studios.</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P>The first broadcast of the film on August 17, 2007 broke records, receiving 17.2 million viewers.<SUP id="cite_ref-variety_4-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-variety-4">[4]</A></SUP> This number made it, at the time, the most-watched basic-cable telecast in history (the previous record was held by an edition of ESPN's <I><A href="/wiki/Monday_Night_Football" title="Monday Night Football">Monday Night Football</A></I> between the <A href="/wiki/New_York_Giants" title="New York Giants">New York Giants</A> and the <A href="/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys" title="Dallas Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</A> on October 23, 2006, which attracted 16 million viewers), the most-watched made-for-cable movie ever (the previous record was held by TNT's January 21, 2001 airing of <I><A href="/wiki/Crossfire_Trail" title="Crossfire Trail">Crossfire Trail</A></I>, which brought in 12.5 million viewers), and the largest audience of any program on broadcast or cable in the 2007 summer television season, along with Friday nights for the past five years. Ratings for the second showing of the movie fell to 8.4 million, and the third showing fell to 7.4 million, totaling the premiere weekend to 33.04 million viewers.<SUP id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-10">[10]</A></SUP></P>
<P>In <A href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</A>, the premiere of <I>High School Musical 2</I> was seen by 3.3 million viewers in the north region. The film was the most-watched in its schedule, among all cable channels, and produced the highest rating of the channel, surpassing all original films of Disney Channel. Among other records, the premiere in <A href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</A> surpassed the debut of <I><A href="/wiki/High_School_Musical" title="High School Musical">High School Musical</A></I> the last year, in a 107 percent, while in <A href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</A> the sequel reached 208 percent, and <A href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</A> did so with 61 percent.<SUP id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-11">[11]</A></SUP> In the <A href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</A>, the movie became <A href="/wiki/Disney_Channel_(UK)" class="mw-redirect" title="Disney Channel (UK)">Disney Channel UK's</A> most viewed program ever, totaling 1.2 million viewers in its first showing.<SUP id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-12">[12]</A></SUP></P>
<P>The film received mixed to positive reviews from critics, gaining a score of 57% on Rotten Tomatoes while gaining a score of 72/100 at <A href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-13">[13]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-14">[14]</A></SUP> <I><A href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</A>'</I>s Robert Bianco awarded the film three stars out of four, saying <I>High School Musical 2</I> was "sweet, smart, bursting with talent and energy, and awash in innocence".<SUP id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-15">[15]</A></SUP> While critics enjoyed the film, they noted that the timing of the movie's premiere seemed odd, premiering just when school was about to start up again, while the movie's plot involved the gang going on summer vacation.<SUP id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-16">[16]</A></SUP> <I>High School Musical 2</I> won the "So Hot Right Now" award at the <A href="/wiki/Nickelodeon_Australian_Kids%27_Choice_Awards_2007" title="Nickelodeon Australian Kids' Choice Awards 2007">Nickelodeon Australian Kids' Choice Awards 2007</A>, in which <I>High School Musical</I> castmate <A href="/wiki/Zac_Efron" title="Zac Efron">Zac Efron</A> hosted with <A href="/wiki/The_Veronicas" title="The Veronicas">The Veronicas</A>.</P>
<H2><SPAN id="High_School_Musical_2:_On_Stage.21"></SPAN><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="High_School_Musical_2:_On_Stage!">High School Musical 2: On Stage!</SPAN></H2>
<DIV role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <A href="/wiki/High_School_Musical_2:_On_Stage!" title="High School Musical 2: On Stage!">High School Musical 2: On Stage!</A></DIV>
<DIV class="thumb tright">
<DIV class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><A href="/wiki/File:HSMcakeshot.JPG" class="image"><IMG alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/87/HSMcakeshot.JPG/250px-HSMcakeshot.JPG" width="250" height="188" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/87/HSMcakeshot.JPG/375px-HSMcakeshot.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/8/87/HSMcakeshot.JPG 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="375" /></A>
<DIV class="thumbcaption">
<DIV class="magnify"><A href="/wiki/File:HSMcakeshot.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></A></DIV>
<A href="/wiki/Pacific_Repertory_Theatre" title="Pacific Repertory Theatre">Pacific Repertory Theatre</A>'s School of Dramatic Arts <I>High School Musical</I> Act 1 Finale.</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P>Like the original <I><A href="/wiki/High_School_Musical" title="High School Musical">High School Musical</A></I>, the sequel has been adapted into two different theatrical productions: a one-act, 70-minute version and a two-act full-length production. This stage production includes the song "Hummuhummunukunukuapua'a" that was left out of the original movie but included in the DVD. Through <A href="/wiki/Music_Theater_International" class="mw-redirect" title="Music Theater International">Music Theater International</A>, Disney Theatrical began licensing the theatrical rights in October 2008. MTI had originally recruited 7 schools to serve as tests for the new full-length adaptation, but due to complications with multiple drafts of both the script and the score, all but two schools were forced to drop out of the pilot program.</P>
<UL>
<LI>On May 18, 2008, Woodlands High School became the first school to produce High School Musical 2.</LI>
<LI>From July 17-August 3, 2008, Harrell Theatre, in Collierville, Tennessee, was the first community theatre to perform the production, which featured both a senior cast and a junior cast.</LI>
<LI>From January 15 - February 15, 2009, the West Coast premiere production was presented by <A href="/wiki/Pacific_Repertory_Theatre" title="Pacific Repertory Theatre">Pacific Repertory Theatre</A>'s School of Dramatic Arts. The production was directed by PacRep founder<A href="/wiki/Stephen_Moorer" title="Stephen Moorer">Stephen Moorer</A>, who previously directed the California premiere of the first High School Musical.<SUP id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-17">[17]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI>From 6–18 April 2009, the UK Premiere was performed by StageDaze Theatre Company in <A href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-18">[18]</A></SUP></LI>
</UL>

<H1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Trade winds</H1>			<DIV id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
				<DIV id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</DIV>				<DIV id="contentSub"></DIV>
								<DIV id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<A href="#mw-head">navigation</A>, 					<A href="#p-search">search</A>
				</DIV>
				<DIV id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><DIV class="mw-parser-output"><DIV role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the weather phenomenon. For other uses, see <A href="/wiki/Tradewind_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Tradewind (disambiguation)">Tradewind</A>.</DIV>
<DIV class="thumb tright">
<DIV class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><A href="/wiki/File:Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png" class="image"><IMG alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png/300px-Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png" width="300" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png/450px-Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png/600px-Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png 2x" data-file-width="1425" data-file-height="625" /></A>
<DIV class="thumbcaption">
<DIV class="magnify"><A href="/wiki/File:Map_prevailing_winds_on_earth.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></A></DIV>
The <A href="/wiki/Westerlies" title="Westerlies">westerlies</A> (blue arrows) and trade winds (yellow and brown arrows)</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P>The <B>trade winds</B> are the <A href="/wiki/Prevailing_winds" title="Prevailing winds">prevailing pattern</A> of easterly surface <A href="/wiki/Wind" title="Wind">winds</A> found in the <A href="/wiki/Tropics" title="Tropics">tropics</A>, within the lower portion of the <A href="/wiki/Earth%27s_atmosphere" class="mw-redirect" title="Earth's atmosphere">Earth's atmosphere</A>, in the lower section of the <A href="/wiki/Troposphere" title="Troposphere">troposphere</A> near the Earth's <A href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">equator</A>. The trade winds blow predominantly from the northeast in the <A href="/wiki/Northern_Hemisphere" title="Northern Hemisphere">Northern Hemisphere</A> and from the southeast in the <A href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</A>, strengthening during the winter and when the <A href="/wiki/Arctic_oscillation" title="Arctic oscillation">Arctic oscillation</A> is in its warm phase. Trade winds have been used by captains of <A href="/wiki/Sailing_ship" title="Sailing ship">sailing ships</A> to cross the world's oceans for centuries, and enabled <A href="/wiki/Colonial_empire" title="Colonial empire">European empire</A> expansion into the Americas and trade routes to become established across the <A href="/wiki/Atlantic_ocean" class="mw-redirect" title="Atlantic ocean">Atlantic</A> and <A href="/wiki/Pacific_ocean" class="mw-redirect" title="Pacific ocean">Pacific oceans</A>.</P>
<P>In <A href="/wiki/Meteorology" title="Meteorology">meteorology</A>, the trade winds act as the <A href="/wiki/Prevailing_winds" title="Prevailing winds">steering flow</A> for <A href="/wiki/Tropical_storms" class="mw-redirect" title="Tropical storms">tropical storms</A> that form over the Atlantic, Pacific, and southern <A href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Oceans</A> and make landfall in North America, Southeast Asia, and Madagascar and eastern Africa, respectively. Trade winds also transport African dust westward across the <A href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</A> into the <A href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">Caribbean Sea</A>, as well as portions of southeastern <A href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</A>. Shallow <A href="/wiki/Cumulus_cloud" title="Cumulus cloud">cumulus clouds</A> are seen within trade wind regimes, and are capped from becoming taller by a trade wind inversion, which is caused by descending air aloft from within the <A href="/wiki/Subtropical_ridge" title="Subtropical ridge">subtropical ridge</A>. The weaker the trade winds become, the more rainfall can be expected in the neighboring landmasses.</P>
<P></P>

<P></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="History">History</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Trade_winds&action=edit&section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<DIV class="thumb tright">
<DIV class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><A href="/wiki/File:Spanish_Galleon.jpg" class="image"><IMG alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Spanish_Galleon.jpg/200px-Spanish_Galleon.jpg" width="200" height="275" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/08/Spanish_Galleon.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="412" /></A>
<DIV class="thumbcaption">
<DIV class="magnify"><A href="/wiki/File:Spanish_Galleon.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></A></DIV>
A Spanish galleon</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <A href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</A>, <A href="/wiki/Volta_do_Mar" class="mw-redirect" title="Volta do Mar">Volta do Mar</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Age_of_sail" class="mw-redirect" title="Age of sail">Age of sail</A></DIV>
<P>The term <I>trade winds</I> originally derives from the early fourteenth century late <A href="/wiki/Middle_English" title="Middle English">Middle English</A> word 'trade,' meaning "path" or "track."<SUP id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-1">[1]</A></SUP> The Portuguese recognized the importance of the trade winds (then the <I><A href="/wiki/Volta_do_mar" title="Volta do mar">Volta do mar</A></I>, meaning in Portuguese "turn of the sea" but also "return from the sea") in navigation in both the north and south Atlantic ocean as early as the 15th century.<SUP id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-2">[2]</A></SUP> From West Africa, the Portuguese had to sail away from continental Portugal, that is, to west and northwest. They could then turn northeast, to the area around the <A href="/wiki/Azores" title="Azores">Azores</A> islands, and finally east to mainland Europe. They also learned that to reach South Africa, they needed to go far out in the ocean, head for Brazil, and around 30°S go east again. Following the African coast southbound means upwind in the Southern hemisphere. In the Pacific ocean, the full wind circulation, which included both the trade wind easterlies and higher-latitude <A href="/wiki/Westerlies" title="Westerlies">Westerlies</A>, was unknown to Europeans until <A href="/wiki/Andres_de_Urdaneta" class="mw-redirect" title="Andres de Urdaneta">Andres de Urdaneta</A>'s voyage in 1565.<SUP id="cite_ref-pg18_3-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-pg18-3">[3]</A></SUP></P>
<P>The captain of a sailing ship seeks a course along which the winds can be expected to blow in the direction of travel.<SUP id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-4">[4]</A></SUP> During the <A href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</A>, the pattern of <A href="/wiki/Prevailing_winds" title="Prevailing winds">prevailing winds</A> made various points of the globe easy or difficult to access, and therefore had a direct effect on European empire-building and thus on modern political geography. For example, <A href="/wiki/Manila_galleon" title="Manila galleon">Manila galleons</A> could not sail into the wind at all.<SUP id="cite_ref-pg18_3-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-pg18-3">[3]</A></SUP></P>
<P>By the 18th century the importance of the trade winds to England's merchant fleet for crossing the Atlantic Ocean had led both the general public and etymologists to identify the name with a later meaning of 'trade', "(foreign) commerce".<SUP id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-5">[5]</A></SUP> Between 1847 and 1849, <A href="/wiki/Matthew_Fontaine_Maury" title="Matthew Fontaine Maury">Matthew Fontaine Maury</A> collected enough information to create wind and current charts for the world's oceans.<SUP id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-6">[6]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Cause">Cause</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Trade_winds&action=edit&section=2" title="Edit section: Cause">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<DIV class="thumb tright">
<DIV class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><A href="/wiki/File:Earth_Global_Circulation_-_en.svg" class="image"><IMG alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Earth_Global_Circulation_-_en.svg/400px-Earth_Global_Circulation_-_en.svg.png" width="400" height="334" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Earth_Global_Circulation_-_en.svg/600px-Earth_Global_Circulation_-_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Earth_Global_Circulation_-_en.svg/800px-Earth_Global_Circulation_-_en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="835" /></A>
<DIV class="thumbcaption">
<DIV class="magnify"><A href="/wiki/File:Earth_Global_Circulation_-_en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></A></DIV>
3D map showing <A href="/wiki/Hadley_cell" title="Hadley cell">Hadley cells</A> in relationship to trade winds on the surface.</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <A href="/wiki/Air_mass" title="Air mass">Air mass</A>, <A href="/wiki/Hadley_cell" title="Hadley cell">Hadley cell</A>, <A href="/wiki/Humidity" title="Humidity">Humidity</A>, <A href="/wiki/Intertropical_Convergence_Zone" title="Intertropical Convergence Zone">Intertropical Convergence Zone</A>, <A href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">Monsoon</A>, <A href="/wiki/Monsoon_trough" title="Monsoon trough">Monsoon trough</A>, <A href="/wiki/Near-equatorial_trough" class="mw-redirect" title="Near-equatorial trough">Near-equatorial trough</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Prevailing_winds" title="Prevailing winds">Prevailing winds</A></DIV>
<P>As part of the <A href="/wiki/Hadley_cell" title="Hadley cell">Hadley cell</A> circulation, surface air flows toward the equator while the flow aloft is towards the <A href="/wiki/Geographic_pole" class="mw-redirect" title="Geographic pole">poles</A>. A <A href="/wiki/Low-pressure_area" title="Low-pressure area">low-pressure area</A> of calm, light variable winds near the equator is known as the <A href="/wiki/Doldrums" title="Doldrums">doldrums</A>,<SUP id="cite_ref-dold_7-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-dold-7">[7]</A></SUP> near-equatorial trough,<SUP id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-8">[8]</A></SUP> intertropical front, or the <A href="/wiki/Intertropical_Convergence_Zone" title="Intertropical Convergence Zone">Intertropical Convergence Zone</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-9">[9]</A></SUP> When located within a <A href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</A> region, this zone of low pressure and wind convergence is also known as the <A href="/wiki/Monsoon_trough" title="Monsoon trough">monsoon trough</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-10">[10]</A></SUP> Around 30° in both hemispheres, air begins to descend toward the surface in subtropical high-pressure belts known as <A href="/wiki/Subtropical_ridge" title="Subtropical ridge">subtropical ridges</A>. The subsident (sinking) air is relatively dry because as it descends, the temperature increases, but the absolute humidity remains constant, which lowers the relative humidity of the air mass. This warm, dry air is known as a superior air mass and normally resides above a maritime tropical (warm and moist) air mass. An increase of temperature with height is known as a temperature inversion. When it occurs within a trade wind regime, it is known as a trade wind inversion.<SUP id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-11">[11]</A></SUP></P>
<P>The surface air that flows from these subtropical high-pressure belts toward the Equator is deflected toward the west in both hemispheres by the <A href="/wiki/Coriolis_effect" class="mw-redirect" title="Coriolis effect">Coriolis effect</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-12">[12]</A></SUP> These winds blow predominantly from the northeast in the <A href="/wiki/Northern_Hemisphere" title="Northern Hemisphere">Northern Hemisphere</A> and from the southeast in the <A href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-Ralph_13-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Ralph-13">[13]</A></SUP> Because winds are named for the direction from which the wind is blowing,<SUP id="cite_ref-HOWTOREAD_14-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-HOWTOREAD-14">[14]</A></SUP> these winds are called the northeasterly trade winds in the Northern Hemisphere and the southeasterly trade winds in the Southern Hemisphere. The trade winds of both hemispheres meet at the <A href="/wiki/Doldrums" title="Doldrums">doldrums</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-dold_7-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-dold-7">[7]</A></SUP></P>
<P>As they blow across tropical regions, air masses heat up over lower latitudes due to more direct sunlight. Those that develop over land (continental) are drier and hotter than those that develop over oceans (maritime), and travel northward on the western periphery of the subtropical ridge.<SUP id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-15">[15]</A></SUP> Maritime tropical air masses are sometimes referred to as trade air masses.<SUP id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-16">[16]</A></SUP> The one region of the <A href="/wiki/Earth" title="Earth">Earth</A> which has an absence of trade winds is the north <A href="/wiki/Indian_ocean" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian ocean">Indian ocean</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-17">[17]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Weather_effects">Weather effects</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Trade_winds&action=edit&section=3" title="Edit section: Weather effects">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<P>Clouds which form above regions within trade wind regimes are typically composed of cumulus which extend no more than 4 kilometres (13,000 ft) in height, and are capped from being taller by the trade wind inversion.<SUP id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-18">[18]</A></SUP> Trade winds originate more from the direction of the poles (northeast in the Northern Hemisphere, southeast in the Southern Hemisphere) during the cold season, and are stronger in the winter than the summer.<SUP id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-19">[19]</A></SUP> As an example, the windy season in the <A href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guianas</A>, which lie at low latitudes in <A href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</A>, occurs between January and April.<SUP id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-20">[20]</A></SUP> When the phase of the <A href="/wiki/Arctic_oscillation" title="Arctic oscillation">Arctic oscillation</A> (AO) is warm, trade winds are stronger within the tropics. The cold phase of the AO leads to weaker trade winds.<SUP id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-21">[21]</A></SUP> When the trade winds are weaker, more extensive areas of rain fall upon landmasses within the tropics, such as <A href="/wiki/Central_America" title="Central America">Central America</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-22">[22]</A></SUP></P>
<P>During mid-summer in the Northern Hemisphere (July), the westward-moving trade winds south of the northward-moving <A href="/wiki/Subtropical_ridge" title="Subtropical ridge">subtropical ridge</A> expand northwestward from the <A href="/wiki/Caribbean_sea" class="mw-redirect" title="Caribbean sea">Caribbean sea</A> into southeastern North America (Florida and Gulf Coast). When dust from the <A href="/wiki/Sahara" title="Sahara">Sahara</A> moving around the southern periphery of the ridge travels over land, rainfall is suppressed and the sky changes from a blue to a white appearance which leads to an increase in red sunsets. Its presence negatively impacts <A href="/wiki/Air_quality" class="mw-redirect" title="Air quality">air quality</A> by adding to the count of airborne particulates.<SUP id="cite_ref-pooraq_23-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-pooraq-23">[23]</A></SUP> Although the Southeast USA has some of the cleanest air in North America, much of the African dust that reaches the United States affects Florida.<SUP id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-24">[24]</A></SUP> Since 1970, dust outbreaks have worsened due to periods of drought in Africa. There is a large variability in the dust transport to the Caribbean and Florida from year to year.<SUP id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-25">[25]</A></SUP> Dust events have been linked to a decline in the health of <A href="/wiki/Coral_reef" title="Coral reef">coral reefs</A> across the Caribbean and Florida, primarily since the 1970s.<SUP id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-26">[26]</A></SUP></P>

documents.title: Trade winds

text: မြန်မာဘာသာ
title: Trade
winds

qas.question: what purpose did seasonal monsoon winds have on trade

single_answer.answer: enabled European empire expansion into the Americas and trade routes to become established across the Atlantic and Pacific oceans

instances.text: enabled European empire expansion into the Americas and trade routes to become established across the Atlantic and Pacific oceans

<P><I><B>Deadpool 2</B></I> is an upcoming American <A href="/wiki/Superhero_film" title="Superhero film">superhero film</A> based on the <A href="/wiki/Marvel_Comics" title="Marvel Comics">Marvel Comics</A> character <A href="/wiki/Deadpool" title="Deadpool">Deadpool</A>, distributed by <A href="/wiki/20th_Century_Fox" title="20th Century Fox">20th Century Fox</A>. It is intended to be the eleventh installment in the <A href="/wiki/X-Men_(film_series)" title="X-Men (film series)"><I>X-Men</I> film series</A>, and a sequel to the 2016 film <I><A href="/wiki/Deadpool_(film)" title="Deadpool (film)">Deadpool</A></I>. The film is directed by <A href="/wiki/David_Leitch_(director)" title="David Leitch (director)">David Leitch</A> from a script by <A href="/wiki/Rhett_Reese" title="Rhett Reese">Rhett Reese</A>, <A href="/wiki/Paul_Wernick" title="Paul Wernick">Paul Wernick</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Ryan_Reynolds" title="Ryan Reynolds">Ryan Reynolds</A>, with Reynolds starring in the title role alongside <A href="/wiki/Josh_Brolin" title="Josh Brolin">Josh Brolin</A>, <A href="/wiki/Morena_Baccarin" title="Morena Baccarin">Morena Baccarin</A>, <A href="/wiki/Julian_Dennison" title="Julian Dennison">Julian Dennison</A>, <A href="/wiki/Zazie_Beetz" title="Zazie Beetz">Zazie Beetz</A>, <A href="/wiki/T.J._Miller" title="T.J. Miller">T.J. Miller</A>, <A href="/wiki/Brianna_Hildebrand" title="Brianna Hildebrand">Brianna Hildebrand</A>, <A href="/wiki/Jack_Kesy" title="Jack Kesy">Jack Kesy</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Stefan_Kapi%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Stefan Kapičić">Stefan Kapičić</A>. In <I>Deadpool 2</I>, Deadpool forms the team <A href="/wiki/X-Force" title="X-Force">X-Force</A> to protect a young mutant from <A href="/wiki/Cable_(comics)" title="Cable (comics)">Cable</A>.</P>
<P>Plans for a sequel to <I>Deadpool</I> began before that film's release, and were confirmed in February 2016. Though the original creative team of Reynolds, Reese, Wernick, and director <A href="/wiki/Tim_Miller_(director)" title="Tim Miller (director)">Tim Miller</A> were quickly set to return for the second film, Miller left the project in October 2016 due to creative differences with Reynolds, and was soon replaced by Leitch. An extensive casting search took place to fill the role of Cable, with Brolin ultimately cast; the casting of Beetz as <A href="/wiki/Domino_(comics)" title="Domino (comics)">Domino</A> was also noteworthy. Filming took place in <A href="/wiki/British_Columbia" title="British Columbia">British Columbia</A>, Canada, from June to October 2017. During filming, stunt woman <A href="/wiki/Joi_Harris" title="Joi Harris">Joi "SJ" Harris</A> died in a motorcycle accident.</P>
<P><I>Deadpool 2</I> is scheduled to be released in the United States on May 18, 2018. A sequel, <I>Deadpool 3</I>, is in development.</P>
<P></P>
